author: By Emma Munbodh
title: Edinburgh city guide: Cheap hotels, value restaurants, travel tips, and sights to see
text:
Thousands of Brits flock to Edinburgh every year for sightseeing, Hogmanay, the International and Fringe arts festivals and more.
Every week in Edinburgh, there seems to be some kind of festival or exciting event going on.
Small enough to walk around, the city highlights can be taken in during a few days strolling around the Castle, Arthur’s Seat and the Museum of Scotland.
Find out more in our Edinburgh city guide below.
For more city break inspiration, see our guide on the 10 best destinations for a long weekend and how to do it on a budget .
Cheap flights and train tickets Edinburgh has a solid tram network, and buses run pretty much everywhere including to Arthur’s Seat .
Virgin Trains provides a service into both Edinburgh city stations. Book two months in advance, and get an off-peak singles from £33.
You can also save up to 43% on tickets, and get 50% off hotels in Edinburgh when you book in advance via the Trainline.
Flying out? Budget airlines like easyJet and Ryanair offer cheap flights all year round, keep an eye out for the sales here for prices as low as £15.
Top hotels on a budget Stay at the Ibis in the city centre for easy access to shops and the wonderful countryside
Tripadvisor has a great price guide on the 30 best hotels in Edinburgh.
Visitors can also bag seriously cheap rooms when booking via Premier Inn , Holiday Inn and Travelodge in advance. All are a short walk from Waverley Train Station. If you're booking last minute, lastminute.com also offer some top late deals throughout the year.
The Ibis Styles is also in a near perfect location just off St Andrew Square, and prices start at £60 a night, including a continental breakfast.
All-in-one tourist passes A two-day Royal Edinburgh Ticket gives entry to Edinburgh Castle, the Palace of Holyroodhouse, the Royal Yacht Britannia, and two consecutive days of travel on several Edinburgh Hop-On-Hop-Off Bus Tours. Adults, £48; child 5-15, £26; seniors/students, £42. edinburghtour.com .
A Historic Scotland Explorer pass gives free entry to any of their 78 paid entry properties around Scotland, including Edinburgh Castle and Craigmillar Castle. A three-day pass is £29; child, £17; concession/student, £24; family, £58. historic-scotland.gov.uk .
For more inspiration on things to do, have a read of Tripadvisor's Edinburgh guide.
Stunning views: Arthur’s Seat volcano Extinct volcano Arthur’s Seat looks over the city towards the water of the Firth of Forth.
Grab a taxi to Dunsapie Loch, and you'll be rewarded with some spectacular views. Try the climb in the early hours and watch the sun rise over an incredible panorama.
Must visit: The Royal Mile Discover the tales of ghosts, murders, and plague victims at The Real Mary Close
The Real Mary King’s Close is, in a literal sense, Edinburgh’s deepest secret.
A warren of streets frozen in time since the 17th century twists its way underneath the Old Town and was closed to the public for many years. Now guides will spend an hour walking you around with tales of ghosts, murders, and plague victims.
Open from 10am every day, prices start at £13.25 for adults and £7.75 for children, realmarykingsclose.com .
Michelin dining on a budget Set up by Martin Wishart, The Honours is an affordable version of his eponymous Michelin starred restaurant over in Leith.
Main courses start at near £17, but a two course prix fixe is £18.50 at certain times of the day (£22.50 for three courses). Book online here .
For cheaper alternatives starting at £4, check out Tripadvisor's 30 best restaurants in Scotland.
Near the George the IV Bridge, Cellar Door is an affordable taste of Scotland using local produce – including haggis, neeps and tatties, Angus beef and salmon are all present, mains around £12 – and service is great.
Pubs to visit A trip to Edinburgh is not complete without at least one dram of whisky
A trip here is not complete without at least one dram of whisky, leaning against the bar of one of its many drinking holes .
The excellent Blue Blazer (2 Spittal Street) has around 50 malts, but most bars and pubs have an extensive selection.
Whiski Rooms has guides to take you through the tipple’s history and how best to taste it.
Upcoming events For a guide to what’s coming up see thisisedinburgh.com .
The city is currently enjoying Edinburgh Science Festival ( sciencefestival.co.uk ) until April 19, and will soon be gearing up for The Imaginate Festival ( imaginate.org.uk ) which runs from May 11 to 17.
